mechanisms.name: Slider-Crank
mechanisms.description: Converts rotational motion of crank to linear motion of slider
mechanisms.text_description: A mechanism that converts rotational motion from a crank into linear or reciprocating motion of a slider; a rotating crank drives a slider back and forth along a guide.

mechanisms.name: Rack and Pinion
mechanisms.description: Converts rotational motion of pinion to linear motion of rack
mechanisms.text_description: A circular gear (pinion) engages a linear gear (rack) to convert rotary input into straight-line translation, commonly used for steering and linear actuation.

mechanisms.name: Spur Gear Pair (External)
mechanisms.description: Converts rotational motion with speed reduction
mechanisms.text_description: Two external spur gears mesh to transmit torque and rotational motion from one shaft to another with opposite rotation and a speed/torque ratio defined by gear teeth.

mechanisms.name: Four-Bar Linkage
mechanisms.description: Converts rotational motion with different output characteristics
mechanisms.text_description: A closed kinematic chain with four revolute joints that converts input rotation into controlled output rotation/oscillation through coupler motion; versatile motion transmission.

mechanisms.name: Cam-Follower
mechanisms.description: Converts rotational motion to complex translational motion
mechanisms.text_description: A rotating cam drives a follower via surface contact to produce a prescribed linear or oscillatory displacement profile; transforms rotary input into tailored motion output.

mechanisms.name: Scotch Yoke
mechanisms.description: Converts rotational motion to sinusoidal translational motion
mechanisms.text_description: A pin on a rotating disk slides in a slot (yoke) to convert rotary motion into near-sinusoidal linear reciprocation with a direct kinematic relationship.

mechanisms.name: Worm and Wheel
mechanisms.description: Converts rotational motion with high reduction ratio
mechanisms.text_description: A screw-like worm drives a worm gear to achieve large speed reduction and torque increase with non-parallel, non-intersecting axes; typically non-backdrivable.

mechanisms.name: Bevel Gear Pair
mechanisms.description: Converts rotational motion between perpendicular axes
mechanisms.text_description: Two bevel gears transmit rotation between intersecting (often perpendicular) shafts, changing axis direction with configurable gear ratio.

mechanisms.name: Slider-Crank with Return Spring
mechanisms.text_description: A slider-crank augmented with a spring to bias or return the slider to a rest position, enabling passive reset or force shaping across the stroke.

mechanisms.name: Double Slider-Crank
mechanisms.description: Converts linear motion to linear motion with different characteristics
mechanisms.text_description: A mechanism with two sliders constrained to orthogonal or guided paths, converting one translational input into another with a specific kinematic relationship.

mechanisms.name: Watt-II Linkage
mechanisms.description: 6-bar linkage for generating sophisticated coupler curves and approximate straight-line motion
mechanisms.text_description: A six-bar linkage configuration (Watt's type II) that produces complex coupler point trajectories; widely used in applications requiring sophisticated motion profiles such as car trunk hinges, folding mechanisms, and approximate straight-line generation.

mechanisms.name: Stephenson-III Linkage
mechanisms.description: Alternative 6-bar configuration for different coupler curves and motion characteristics
mechanisms.text_description: A Stephenson III six-bar linkage providing alternative coupler curve characteristics compared to Watt mechanisms; used in packaging machinery, robotic arms, and prosthetic limb applications where specific motion profiles are required.

mechanisms.name: Scissors Mechanism
mechanisms.description: Pantograph-style mechanism providing high expansion ratios for vertical or horizontal translation
mechanisms.text_description: A scissors-type or pantograph mechanism that provides mechanical advantage through geometric amplification; creates large displacement from small input, commonly used in scissor lifts, adjustable lamp arms, and expandable structures.

mechanisms.name: Flexure Hinge
mechanisms.description: Monolithic compliant hinge using material flexibility instead of pin joints
mechanisms.text_description: A compliant mechanism that achieves rotation through elastic deformation of a thin flexure section rather than traditional pin joints; offers zero friction, no backlash, and maintenance-free operation, ideal for precision instruments and MEMS devices.

satisfies_efs.notes: Inherent return spring due to elastic restoring force

mechanisms.name: Living Hinge
mechanisms.description: Thin material section allowing repeated bending in molded plastic parts
mechanisms.text_description: A compliant hinge formed by a thin section of plastic material that allows repeated bending; commonly seen in shampoo bottle caps, toolbox lids, and snap-fit assemblies. Provides low-cost hinges in injection-molded parts.

mechanisms.name: Geneva Drive
mechanisms.description: Converts continuous rotation into precise indexed steps with dwell periods
mechanisms.text_description: An indexing mechanism that converts continuous rotary input into intermittent rotary output with precise angular positioning and dwell periods; the driving wheel has a pin that engages slots in the driven wheel. Used extensively in film projectors, automatic tool changers, and indexing tables.

mechanisms.name: Ratchet and Pawl
mechanisms.description: Allows motion in one direction while preventing reverse motion through mechanical locking
mechanisms.text_description: A mechanical device consisting of a toothed wheel (ratchet) and a pivoting lever (pawl) that permits rotation in one direction while preventing motion in the opposite direction; essential for winches, tie-down straps, and anti-reverse mechanisms.

mechanisms.name: Toggle Mechanism
mechanisms.description: Provides mechanical advantage near toggle position for clamping and pressing operations
mechanisms.text_description: A linkage mechanism that achieves very high mechanical advantage when approaching the toggle (over-center) position; used in clamps, presses, and latching mechanisms where large output forces are needed from small input forces.

mechanisms.name: Quick-Return Mechanism
mechanisms.description: Converts uniform rotation into reciprocating motion with different forward and return speeds
mechanisms.text_description: A mechanism that produces reciprocating motion where the forward stroke takes longer than the return stroke (or vice versa); commonly used in shaper machines, mechanical saws, and applications requiring fast return with slow working stroke.
